Topic.Title: Many Long-time Shorts Have Thrown In The Towel

Message.Msg: Yeah, the guy who thought selling at $130 was a good idea thought the same thing. He ended up missing the run to $260. If you're so worried about losing your gain just sell after you have a profit above 5% or above a CD. $300 is not a magic number, nor is $300. If you will be happy with just a small gain that is fine, sell at anytime. A lot of people say the will be "happy". Only thing is that after they see the stock double right after they sold they turn out not to be so happy after all. Also, I don't see how one can set a price in advance. By the time the stock is at $300 or $350 we may have all kinds of new data and issues to consider; there's no way to "set a price" today unless you are just playing a game. If it is a game, just flip a coin and let heads be $300 and tails be $350.

Time to blow the whistle!!!

Message.Title: Still Another Translation of Techstrategy's Nonsense
Message.Msg: "If the institutional longs are ever going to get real investors to come back into the market..." = "the reason my short is losing so much money is because of the institutions and if they would just go away I would be fine." But the problem is they are not going to go away. So you will always have big losses. Whenever they have gone away it has been for very short periods of time that really don't matter to anyone long-term oriented, and when they come back the stock is a lot higher than it was before and 99% of the people who were short end up giving up all their gains on the way back up anyway. "I'm not the least bit concerned." = "I am very, very worried, but will pretend to be 'not the least bit concerned' and see if I can bluff my way through another post. If I short more at $265 and it keeps going up my goose will really be cooked!"

Message.Title: Subpoena for Amazon...
Message.Msg: Like I said, Apple is going to go after Amazon hard. It seems our friends from Amazon are trying to quash a subpoena that was filed in conjunction with the eBooks anti-trust case. I guess Amazon doesn't want to have its entire business strategy of predatory pricing exposed... Microsoft, Apple and Google have all taken their turn getting beaten up on the PR / Anti-trust front. Looks like Apple is going to make sure Amazon has its dirty little secrets exposed too... For those keeping score, I suspect that Apple and the publishers settled in Europe because they now realize the best strategy is to let Apple starve Amazon of cash flow by competing on price for a year or two...

"I suspect that Apple and the publishers settled in Europe because they now realize the best strategy is to let Apple starve Amazon" More evidence of how worried you are. It is obvious that Apple settled because they broke the law and they know it. Breaking the law was a defensive move on their part, to buy some time, but their time is now up. Anyone who doesn't see that (you) must be desperate to make up some #$%$and-bull spin story about how Apple and publishers now being forced to compensate consumers they had cheated into a "positive" thing for shorts. If Amazon's use of loss leaders is some kind of scam, then Walmart is the biggest scammer of them all.
Except QE can't save a certain class of companies like Apple and Google from losing share to a higher class of company like Amazon from stealing more and more share away from them.

Yeah, Amazon will get 100% share of things in which there are literally no economic profit. Apple and Google will see to it that its historical cash cows come under attack. Got to love the strategy of going big just in time for the fiscal cliff and consumer retrenchment.

As more and more states start to charge sales tax on AMZN purchases, sales will move to other sites. AMZN growth will slow. Bezos will be able to hide it for a while (he's good at that), but at some point the game will end. AMZN to $20 long term.
Texas is another.
No, taxes will mean that they grow about 500% times faster than shorts had anticipated rather than 510% more. Hardly moves the needle.
Nope not today short pig sorry ): See you at $275 (:

Not only am I not concerned, I increased my investment today... Apple was simply trying to compete on experience rather than price and replicate the model that had been used successfully and to the benefit of all in the music industry. Apple's subpoena will expose Amazon as the entity truly engaged in predatory behavior... Having said that, iPads now have a mature ecosystem. They didn't need the publishing industry because the ecosystem was already sufficiently differentiated from music, apps and Apple's software. Now, Apple realizes that it can get aggressive in pricing eBooks and go after Amazon's core...

Taxes matter. Add 6% to the sale price of a high dollar item and I am looking for a cheaper alternative. There are other websites that sell without the 6% markup (in my state). It will have an impact, open your eyes.

Message.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess
Message.Msg: "Yeah, Amazon will get 100% share of things in which there are literally blah, blah, blah..." If this were so then Apple would never have been so fearful as to try and fix prices breaking the law. Google spent $millions all for naught trying to digitize all the books in the world so worried were they about Amazon. But the Google project was one big flop leaving them with 100% of nothing. Failing to understand a single thing about the retail business can lead you to short Amazon from $180 and to re-enter at $230. What a fine mess El Nano Brain has gotten himself into.

Message.Title: Big Money Selling AMZN on Stregnth Today - in Top 3
Message.Msg: AMZN 3rd highest sold by Big Holders. Can't blame them at these levels.

I guess Amazon couldn't have gone local before 2012 and charged sales tax? Based upon my understand of tax law, Amazon was free to build a local presence in any state so long as it collected taxes.... Nonetheless, for some reason it chose not to all these years... The pumpers would like naive retail investors to believe that Amazon now is magically able to build out warehouses and sell locally and that the growth rate will go parabolic as a result. Let's be 100% perfectly clear. Amazon had the choice to built out local presences and collect taxes since it was founded. It had chosen not to, presumably because it viewed paying taxes as disadvantageous... All we know is that Amazon always had the freedom to do it, but chose not to until such time as multiple states were enacting laws that would force it to collect taxes... Pump Neme pump!

"replicate the model that had been used successfully and to the benefit of all in the music industry." Where were you when iTunes was born? Where have you been since? I believe you have never bought a Tune from iTunes in your life. Otherwise you would realize that what Amazon was doing pricing all those e-books at $9.99 was the same thing Apple was doing by pricing their music at $0.99, the lowest price in the industry at that time. Now I can see from your ignorance about all matters relating to online retail why are are not worried. You're in over your head and your lack of information has you rendered you incapable of knowing just how deep.

The growth needn't be parabolic. The problem for shorts is if they were expecting negative growth or growth of only 5% or 10% or whatever, and growth turns out to be 30% or 40% instead, something far less than "parabolic", shorts eat crow. Ya dig?

" Amazon was free to build a local presence in any state so long as it collected taxes" More ignorance. The law until changed was that the consumer (you and other shorts) was supposed to forward sales tax to the local government agency. The question that is more pertinent is why didn't you do that?

Topic.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess

Message.Msg: Apple wasn't fearful of Amazon in the slightest. Apple was simply trying to adopt a model for publishers consistent with what was adopted in music a decade before that had worked to the benefit of everyone. If the publishers are smart, they will increase prices for digital content across the board and share more of the economic rents with the authors themselves, focusing on discovery and development of talent. Amazon will simply be another digital distribution channel....

Obviously you would rather try to distract people from the clear inescapable logic. If taxes did not matter, then Amazon could have built a local presence at any time. It simply would have been responsible for collecting sales tax as it is now. It chose not to because it knew that collecting taxes would adversely affect its business.

Topic.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess

Message.Msg: "Apple was simply trying to adopt a model for publishers consistent with what was adopted in music a decade before that had worked to the benefit of everyone." Must be off your rocker. Music companies were devastated by the system Apple forced on them. It was not to the "benefit" of everyone. Only someone ignorant of the history of online music could say such a silly thing. In addition Apple's policy with music was to LOWER prices as low as possible. For e-books, it was to RAISE prices. You need to get your story straight and stop making up REVISIONIST nonsense. "If the publishers are smart, they will increase prices for digital content across the board" They'd like to but it is against the law to do so. It's called price fixing. Are you saying it is smart to break the law, be forced to pay hefty fines, and be ordered by the government to cease and desist such unlawful activity. That's smart?

No. When Apple launched iTunes the minimum price was $0. Piracy of digital content was rampant and the music industry badly needed to slow it down. Apple proposed a solution that involved charging a lower price and allowing consumers to choose a la cart that was low enough to gradually eliminate the incentive to listen to pirated music. Amazon, in contrast, is trying to leverage its market power in physical and eBooks against the publishing industry to set price at levels that others (aside from Apple or Google selling at cost) would not be able to match. It will be Amazon and not Apple that has legal/anti-trust issues in time...

Message.Title: Why Amazon Did Not Go Local Before 2012
Message.Msg: "Amazon could have built a local presence at any time." Not really. If you're going to go local the best time to do so is when you have several $billion in cash to fund that kind of move, rather than when you don't such as they did not several years ago. Also, why would you bother with it when the law states that it is the consumer (you and the other shorts who were breaking the law) that is obligated under prior law to forward the sales tax?

Topic.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess

Message.Msg: You are getting schooled Nem... I already pointed out that Apple, through iTunes, dramatically reduced piracy and brought an industry back from the brink that was suffering from pirated content (price of $0...). Also, your willful misreprentation notwithstanding, I did not suggest that they collude. I suggested that it would be good business strategy for each of the publishers to realize that they should significantly increase the price of their digital content provided to Amazon. Doing so would be entirely legal... It would afford them higher margins and profitability, and enable them to invest in talent discovery and development. Amazon would see it's profits and leverage sink....

"When Apple launched iTunes the minimum price was $0...Apple proposed a solution that involved charging a lower price" Huh? How is $0.99 lower than $0? "gradually eliminate the incentive to listen to pirated music." Hahah! This character thinks pirated music has been "eliminated"! "Amazon, in contrast, is trying to leverage its market power in physical and eBooks against the publishing industry to set price at levels that others (aside from Apple or Google selling at cost) would not be able to match." Huh? Walmart has done this for ages, why does it only matter when Amazon does this? "It will be Amazon and not Apple that has legal/anti-trust issues in time..." This is too funny, but typical short thinking. Timber told everyone on this board that the DOJ against Apple on e-book pricing would never see the light of day. And low and behold...

Topic.Title: Why Amazon Did Not Go Local Before 2012

Message.Msg: Funny. I guess Amazon should have done so before it burned all its cash on the Kindle Fire... It had billions more in cash a few years ago...

Actually, it does. Amazon is already trading at a multiple of about 40X TTM operating cash flow. 58X EBITDA. If revenue growth isn't parabolic, AMZN will not see true margin expansion. The longs are in for an additional surprise in terms of declining profitability. Amazon is spending a lot of money on TV advertising. Given its relatively paltry cash flow and the fact that TV advertising usually is better suited to long term brand building than generating transactions, it better hope for a miracle in response...

Topic.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess

Message.Msg: "I already pointed out that Apple, through iTunes, dramatically reduced piracy and brought an industry back from the brink that was suffering from pirated content (price of $0...)." You make no sense. Under the agency pricing publishers got the same amount of money as they did when Amazon was selling books for $9.99. Whatever price Amazon sold e-books for had zero, I repeat, zero effect on the revenue publishers received per e-book. Before Apple got involved with music you are saying music companies got 0%. On the other hand, before Apple got involved in raising prices, publishers got 100% of what publishers always got for e-books. AFTER Apple got involved publishers got the SAME 100%. The only difference was that Apple got more of the revenue that was over and above the cost of the e-book. Who's "schooling" how? "I did not suggest that they collude." So how do they do this? Randomly price content? People never are able to do this. The only way it would work is by colluding by ESP. Unless a standard price is decided one company will always be worried about being underpriced by another. The only way a standard can decided is by collusion. "Amazon would see it's profits and leverage sink...." You'd like to see this happen, but fantasies about collusion without colluding is not gonna get you there.

Message.Title: Ad Spending? Ho-Hum...
Message.Msg: "If revenue growth isn't parabolic, AMZN will not see true margin expansion." Don't worry your little head about it. Rapid growth less than parabolic will be fine. Margins will expand, too. Maybe even hyperbolically, too. You know as much about math as you do about retail I can see. "Amazon is spending a lot of money on TV advertising." So what? What they spend compared to other companies of their size hardly moves the needle. "TV advertising usually is better suited to long term brand building than generating transactions" Well, since Kindle has been on TV sales have gone parabolic so it must be the rare exception to your "rule". If ad spending issue was supposed to help you shorts, you can give it up now, and throw in the towel. A total non-issue.

Message.Title: sell tax old strong buy
Message.Msg: buyyyyyy

Topic.Title: Why Amazon Did Not Go Local Before 2012

Message.Msg: You misunderstand the reason for having a lot of cash to begin with. You have to use to further build your business. Which is what Amazon is doing. And no, they shouldn't have done it before spending a fraction of it on Kindle Fire, they actually did it ongoing with all these other projects. Unlike you they are capable of multi-tasking.

Message.Title: selllllll last year not new strong buy

Topic.Title: How Techstrategy Got Himself Into Another Fine Mess

Message.Msg: Nemesis: You make ZERO sense, but then again, that is your objective. To misdirect and mislead. Because of DRM (and iTunes), piracy has been largely put in check (that is aside from the porn you are always watching...). The music industry has been able to profit from fair pricing under a standard model. Ultimately, publishers set the price of eBooks too low and now should increase those prices to reflect the reality that the value is in the content itself, not in the form in which the content is delivered. Publishers would simply have to recognize where their value added is and alter their pricing strategy accordingly. You are correct that most industries follow some form of price leadership model, so presumably when one increases its prices on the digital format across the board, others are highly likely to follow. I'm done for the day. I'll correct your other misrepresentation and misdirections another time...

Message.Title: sellllll tax last year not new strong buy

Message.Title: $265 and up to $270 by the end of the week
Message.Msg: Grab ur ankles shorties, it's gonna hurt!!!! lol

Message.Title: The Top
Message.Msg: Whenever this clown Nemesis starts chirping, it's time to short. He's a poor seventh grade teacher from a third rate school in LA. His Japanese mother threw herself off the cliffs when the Americans appeared on the horizon. He owns 300 shares and got margined out during the 2008/9 crash and has never mentally or financially recovered. When he starts spurting his complete garbage about Amazon, just short or buy some put spreads. Time to get back in......

This isn't the top yet. We are on the CMG like ascent. Based on prior experience fighting that scam, I'd say we could have another 4 months before this breaks down. Just make sure you can ride through 330 for another year if necessary (if you can, you will make a fortune. If you cannot, the predators will eat you before you get a chance to feast). The entire market is massively overdue for a correction, but it will keep running until people realize that QEternity fails. Nominal GDP gains mean nothing. Unless and until median real disposable income grows significantly, this stock and all other consumer stocks are hosed.
Amazon will not show 30% growth even with the Bezos magical accounting method.

amzn is no walmart - walmart generated fantastic margins throughout their entire expansion phase. amzn 's margin is horrible during their expansion phases and very lack luster after expansion phase. history is clear on this. the stock is priced on phantom margins.

The Fed is buying RMBS and treasuries. Anyone stupid enough to hold that is going to park their money in cash assets. The Weimar Republic theory of investing in stocks every time QE1, QE2, or QE3 gets considered has always made me laugh. They're pumping cash in because the economy is fragged, not because they have another options. And just to consider a second, if you had excess cash, would you rather put it in a stock trading at 12 or 15 x earnings with moderate growth, or a stock at ~100 Forward P/E with substantial risks to disappointment. Y'all can do the momentum trade as much as you want, but sooner or later reality is going to set in.

Message.Title: AMZN not a SELL until its PE exceeds 1000!
Message.Msg: LMFAO...the delusions of crowds. Now AMZN is priced like, you guessed it, MANY Internet and Tech Stocks during the last 1998-2000 Tech Stock/Internet Bubble. I remember selling stocks with little or no earnings at $850+ per share. It was sheer lunacy. Of course, AMZN actually HAS a PE (grossly overpriced as it surely is), whereas some of the "gems" back then sporting $500+ per share valuations didn't even have earnings, just a price. Really? Do AMZN investors expect this path to continue indefinitely? The cascading crash in AMZN's stock value will be a site to behold once the delusions of the crowds face up to the reality that AMZN now has a "fantasyland" valuation (just like a LEGIT stock such as Qualcomm had about 12 years ago) that can never EVER be achieved.

Topic.Title: Why Amazon Did Not Go Local Before 2012

Message.Msg: Billions to fund? they have $5B in cash however with over $7B in AP and $4B in accrued expenses and sales of what we are told will be $63B this year - not exactly a cash cow. They have $1.4B less than last year and certainly this upcoming quarter will be worse. They're going to need a lot more cash than they have to chase the same day delivery goal which is why they will probably need to issue debt sometime in 2014. Everyday amzns' balance sheet looks more ike a target or best buy. Which is perfectly fine however stock is priced on future cash flow that will never materialize.
Anyone shorting this market is insane, AMZN goin much higher. To many peeps underestimate the FED, what part of 40 bil a month don't people understand?

Topic.Title: Why Amazon Did Not Go Local Before 2012

Message.Msg: You need to look at the balance sheet as of Jun. It is much worse than that $2.3B in cash, $2.4B in receivables, $4.4B in inventory and $2.6B in ST investments against $10.9B in payable. It literally bet the farm on Kindle Fire HD and moving local. If Apple and Google attack its cash flow via price competition on its core digital content (books), amazon is gonna feel some serious hurt.

We understand the part where almost none of that money actually makes it into the hands of the people with the highest marginal propensity to consume. But, please keep buying indiscriminately. It will allow a few more of the badly trapped institutions to get out and will accelerate the downfall...

Message.Title: Good news for shorts.
Message.Msg: Good news: Asian markets crashing tonight! China down 12.37%. Nikkei down 6.41%. Hang Seng down 11.81%. Bad News: AMZN traded in Tokyo Stock Exchange is up 3.2%. Damn, shorts here are the unluckiest people I've ever met.
